discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
vault secrets enable transit enables the Transit Engine at transit/ as shown below:
https://developer.hashicorp.com/vault/docs/secrets/transit#setup

questions.question_text: Which statement describes the results of this command: $ vault secrets enable transit?

choices.B: Requires a root token to execute the command successfully
choices.C: Enables the transit secrets engine at secret path
choices.E: Fails because the transit secrets engine is enabled by default
choices.A: Enables the transit secrets engine at transit path

questions.question_text:
Running the second command in the GUI CU will succeed.
//IMG//

discussion.content:
B

This command will not work in the CI GUI, because as the screenshot shows, from the CU GUI only the commands read, kv-get, write, delete and list are allowed; the command is valid but must be executed from the OS terminal after login.

A

Is the only method not allowed

Selected Answer: A
Only A is not listed here https://developer.hashicorp.com/vault/docs/concepts/tokens#root-tokens

choices.D: By using vault operator generate-root with the permission of a quorum of unseal key holders
choices.C: The initial root token generated at the vault operator init time

questions.question_text: Which of these options does not allow the creation of a root token?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Flags always take precedence over Environment Variables
https://developer.hashicorp.com/vault/docs/commands#environment-variables

questions.question_text:
You manage two Vault dusters: “vaultduster1.acme.corp” and “vaultduster2.acme.corp”. You want to write a secret to the first Vaultcluster vaultcluster1.acme.corp and run vault kv put secret/foo value=‘bar’. The command times out and the error references the Vault cluster, “vaultcluster2.acme.corp”.
You run the command again with the following address flag:
vault kv put -address=‘https://vaultcluster1.acme.corp’ secret/foo value=‘bar’
The command completes successfully. You find that the terminal session defines the environment variable VAULT_ADDR=‘https://vaultcluster2.acxe.corp:8200’
Why was the second attempt successful?

choices.A: Environment variables take precedence over flags
choices.C: Flags take precedence over environment variables

questions.question_text:
The ‘alpha’ secrets are stored in the team-based paths using this convention: secret/<team_name>/alpha. For example, secret/team01/alpha and /secrets/team02/alpha.
Which Vault policy would not allow reading paths with the word “beta” in them, such as secrets/team01/beta?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
While indeed B allows reads on 'secrets/beta/alpha', the question asks about reads on nested secrets under the secrets/teamX/beta path. 'secrets/beta/' itself has nothing to do with the question. B doesn't give access to the teamX/beta path and is correct.

D. 

Additional deny pattern to be set for beta

C

A would allow secrets/team01/beta and B /secrets/team01/beta/alpha

Selected Answer: C
A would allow "secrets/beta" and B would allow "secrets/beta/alpha" so C seems correct.
